subject: Re: [junit] Re: Fork each test method?
msgSnippet: ... Why should the class have its own data? ... I would think that the easiest way to zero out all the caches is to create new cache objects. That s the point
messageBody:
>So said robert_difalco on 2003-06-16 --------------------
>Sure, loosely coupled systems are great, definitely a goal. However,
>sometimes certain things just are coupled, like a subclass to it's
>superclass. The class data for the superclass should exist before
>the subclass, etc.

Why should the class have its own data?

>Also, sometimes the more loosely coupled something is, the HARDER it
>is to reset it's cached data (across all interactions). And I guess
>this is really the problem. I want to zero out all cached data
>without having to know about the couplings that were created
>dynamically.

I would think that the easiest way to zero out all the caches is to create new cache objects. That's the point of a loosely-coupled system. If a class uses a cache, then that class should either accept the cache from the outside world or be unaware that it's using a cache at all.

Caching is more of an extra service that should be implemented as a Decorator. The application should decide to add caching when it strings objects together to form the application. Either that or components should make caching configurable.

Google "Abstraction and detail".

Take care.
